title_suggestions: Electrical Engineering vs Computer Science: Key Differences Explained
What I Wish I Knew: EE vs CS Degree Comparison
Electrical Engineering or Computer Science? A Recent Graduate's Honest Review
timestamps: 02:15 Shared coursework: Math, programming, digital systems
04:45 Key differences: Databases and operating systems
05:45 Algorithms and machine learning theory gaps in EE
06:45 What EE has that CS doesn't: electronics and control theory
10:30 Final advice and career path recommendations
description: Recent EE graduate Alex breaks down the key similarities and differences between Electrical Engineering and Computer Science degrees, covering coursework, career paths, and real-world applications. Whether you're choosing between the two fields or curious about each discipline, this video offers practical insights from someone who's experienced both.
linkedin_post:
Just finished watching a fantastic breakdown of Electrical Engineering vs Computer Science by a recent grad who's lived both paths. Key takeaway: EE offers incredible flexibility—you can pivot to software, physics, renewable energy, or FPGAs. CS is more specialized, requiring stronger commitment to coding from day one.

If you're undecided about your engineering path, EE gives you more optionality. Both degrees develop exceptional problem-solving skills, but the career trajectories diverge significantly. The skills you build—data handling, systems thinking, coding—are universally valuable, but the foundation matters.

Choosing between them? Know yourself first.
twitter_post: EE vs CS: EE gives flexibility across physics, software, renewable energy & FPGAs. CS is narrower but specialized. Both build amazing skills—just pick based on your interests in coding & hardware. 🔌💻
